output: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper very much, that we are coming up with the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the consequences of diseases.
Unfortunately, we are falling short of the food policy in Europe, no matter whether we are talking about NERVET profiles, about food labels or, at some points, about a very one-sided approach.
We are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
And I believe that it is fundamentally wrong to assume that there are good and bad food sources.
Many amendments show that. That doesn't exist.
There are only good and bad or balanced and unbalanced ways of eating.
That should be our approach.
The causes of malnutrition are many.
To prevent this by trying to guide the consumer through product labels or even to go with advertising bans or regulations or different values will not lead us to the goal.

I don't want to start a debate on the classification of food, but I think that everything we do here should be written down a bit. What can we do to motivate consumers to think about their eating habits?
A traffic light sign that suggests that I am facing a good or bad product is, in my opinion, more of an instrument of demoralization than of education and education.
Therefore, I wish for a more balanced approach and the realization that the way forward in the product policy alone will not lead us anywhere. Thank you.
President, Mrs. Vice President, dear colleagues, the household control has no new topics.
We are satisfied with the old ones and we would be satisfied with progress on the old topics.
Five points. First of all, our urgent request for the support of Romania and Bulgaria in the construction of the rule of law, justice and financial control.
In two years we don't want to be where we are today. That's why this point is very important to us.
The second point is the declaration of reliability for the total budget after the standardized control procedure under the integration of the national accounting offices.
It would be nice if we could achieve decisive progress in the last half year, that the Commission only remains, or at least agree on a common path.
You are being modest as a household administrator.
The third point would be the simplification
We must help the lower levels of government of Member States more in implementing the EU law
It is clear that they are completely overwhelmed by the vast majority of EU law, which is why there are high rates of error.
The fourth point, the foreign aid. Here I would like to address the Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Household Control Committee was in Kosovo and I would like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the relief of household expenses.
I believe that we have remained far below the European Union's capabilities and that we urgently need to work on this.
The fifth point is the improvement of cooperation between member states in fraud prevention.
We have homework here, especially for the ladies and gentlemen of the council.

In November, the Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the regulation for the fight against fraud. And then we have to think together how we can continue if we want to achieve better results in this field.
That was our common wish so far.
Thank you, Mr. President. India and Europe need more and better contacts on all levels, especially on the level of so-called normal people.
business travelers, tourists, students and so on. A short note on this. It also has a significant impact on the Commission's legislative program, which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic we need good safety regulations, such as bring something and not just alibi measures.
It would therefore be a reasonable, really necessary measure to finally raise the senseless Liquid's regulations and come up with something better.
I voted for the resolution because it is a clear demand of the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship with the questionable, yes, falsified parliamentary elections of September were not fulfilled.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.

At the same time, today we have called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify the contacts between peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
the reduction of the visa fees for Belarusian citizens who are traveling to Schengen and thus prevent an increasing isolation from Belarus and its citizens.
I would like to first defend the spirit of a statement I heard a few minutes ago, that foreigners would flood our labour market.
Secondly, I would have liked a clearer and clearer report from the employment committee.
Trust in the social binding force of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary rights.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council of the Commission of Member States and the EUGH and not give ourselves satisfaction by simply demanding a balance between fundamental rights and the freedom of the market and the freedom of the market.
We will not change that. Social basic rights are just as much as freedom rights, human rights, which should not be restricted by the free will of the domestic market.
And it is about defending and improving the European social model. And the best time is for the introduction of a social progress clause as binding protocol to the existing EU treaties
And it is time to change the dispensing guideline in such a way that wage and minimum standard demands are not limited to minimum demands. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank the reporter Doris Back, who has already been fully rightly addressed by many colleagues.
We have someone with her who actually, hopefully not spills the blood of her heart, but invests a lot of blood of her heart in this room.
I am happy with you and the colleagues who have also said that there have been some progress, also in the field of police cooperation.
This is important so that the real life can work properly on site.

Nevertheless, I believe that we, our partners in Bosnia and Herzegovina, must point out again and again that a lot of things must be brought in by you, by your side, probably even more than is currently being brought in in some areas.
The internal cooperation, the willingness to work together within the ethnic groups is something we have to demand permanently.
It's not like everyone is trying to find their own way.
and also the integration into regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
Thank you very much, Mrs. President. The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not be as large as it has become.
We have to make sure that it is reduced.
In this context, the civil servant is assigned an important task, especially when and where he does it well.
It is above all about the fact that we have to expect the citizens' commission to be committed and to be able to see the potential.
It is about not raising too high expectations that no one can cover up.

On the other hand, it is about the fact that everywhere in the administration of European institutions, misdeeds are being raised. These are being tackled and, if possible, reasonable solutions are being sought here, which can then ensure and satisfy the citizens.
The previous practice has shown that the civil servant is doing this task seriously and well.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case and thank him and the reporter for this report.

Dear colleagues, Europe is in a difficult crisis ten years after the implementation of the monetary union.
Banks are collapsing or are being supported by billions of euros from the state budget. The deficit is breaking in and millions of people are fearing for their jobs and their future.
But not only the market has failed. Even the ruling political system seems to be incapable of learning from its mistakes.
We are of the opinion that, even with such interim remarks you cannot be particularly profiled, that during the construction of the economic and monetary union serious mistakes were made.
One such mistake is the structural fall of money and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without harmonizing the policy of taxes and spending at least in approaches.
I think the economic imbalances in the eurozone have become enormously exacerbated.
What we need now is a better coordination of the economy and of the tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping. In addition, tax oases must be closed and capital transport must finally be controlled again.
The second grave mistake is the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

In times like these, those who consider consolidating households to be inaccessible are obviously living in a different world. Nothing would be more fatal than reacting to this economic crisis with public savings programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly proven its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
We think it is necessary to launch an investment offensive to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of the socially disadvantaged in Europe.
A third mistake is the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to any democratic control and is only committed to the goal of price stability.

We are committed to democratically controlling the European Central Bank. We also demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy order, which will have to be supported by growth and employment at least equally with price stability in the future.
The current crisis also offers a chance for deep-rooted reforms of the European currency and financial architecture.
This chance should not be played lightly.
Thank you very much, Mrs. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Vice-President, dear colleagues. In fact, the automotive industry is in crisis and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has once again forced the crisis in this sector and the Member States are currently working on ways to solve it.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And that is why we need European solutions for this European key industry to overcome the crisis.
Almost all car companies are based on European structures.

And to be able to make necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, which have been mentioned several times here today, to be able to operate on environmentally friendly and low-consumption technologies, the car manufacturers, public authorities or the European Investment Bank need interest-friendly agents.
but also the delivery industry, which is very important to me, should not be forgotten.
Especially in the supply industry, small and medium-sized companies are where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the last plenary session, the Council President made a proposal to protect key industries
A good proposal, I think. If you think this proposal through, it means a Volkswagen Act for the entire European automobile industry
and this would certainly be a good instrument
But this protective instrument is currently being fought by the European Commission.

And here is my question to the European Commission. Will the European Commission hold a claim in spite of the crisis in the automotive industry? Or will this course be changed in the face of the crisis?
Dear President, President of the European Accounting Office, Vice President of the European Commission, dear colleagues, dear colleagues, in fact, it has become a tradition to establish
that in the relationship between expenses on a European level and administration on a national level, a declaration of reliability cannot be shared for repeated occasions.
I remember talking to Professor Friedmann, former president of the Rechnungshof, who once told me that it is not possible at all to give a reliability statement on the basis of the structures.
That is why we should think about how this instrument can be fulfilled with life, so that the goal of the declaration of reliability, if it is justified, can also be achieved.
And of course we have to distinguish a few things from each other.
First, a household that contains around 95% of subsidies is much more fraudulent than a national household, a regional or a municipal household.

A subsidy budget that is essentially managed by the member states, which in the new financial period have demanded much more of our independence, because the accusation of the last funding period was that it would be controlled too centrally.
This means that the responsibility for the money has to be taken over regionally and nationally.
And I would like to briefly address the third area of topics.
We have to learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These are things that are always thrown together.
I also get annoyed when EU funds are used to fund things that are not necessarily necessary.
But that was not fraud, it was waste.

That is why those who are responsible for the projects, especially in the field of structural policy, the member states, are also responsible for the fact that money is not wasted and that only the projects that are really promoted that really develop an added value for the region.
That's why I think we should think about it, to convert parts of the structural policy into interest-free loans.
If Member States have to pay back, they only promote what they really need. Thank you very much.
It is not only difficult for me to agree to this emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to the handling of the financial market crisis.
Because if Europe, if this EU were a functioning democracy, we would first have to ask the question of responsibility and how all this could have happened.
It's simply not true that all the problems we have in front of us would be a tsunami, something that is natural law, but it was done by human hands.
And with all the regulation rage that this union has exerted, one wonders why it was not acted upon when banks of considerable scale have begun to cross national borders.
Why did not they act despite the corresponding warnings when the derivatives have become so narrow?
I remember well that the Nobel Prize winner Joseph Stieglitz was here, and addressed all these points.
There was silence, there was a taboo.
You would have to take action because in the recognition of one's own mistakes, the key is the solution in the future.
Thank you, Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen. Mr. Commissioner, my question is about what you think about the fact that if Iceland and Hungary introduced the euro as a secondary currency,
Do you think that this could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is, do you think it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the bank's own capital

wouldn't it be more reasonable to think about tax reduction for our companies and for our employees, that we pay investment premiums, that we write down the progressive tax
and that we increase the amount of small-scale economic goods by 10%, so that no interest is taxed, so that the money stays in the companies and that the wages can be paid better.
Thank you, Mrs. President. The comprehensive report shows how many human rights violations are happening in the world every day.
This is particularly frightening 60 years after the declaration of the Human Rights Charter and calls us to further strengthen the efforts.
This is also why I would like to stand up for the current Under-Secretary of Human Rights to be appointed as the main committee.
Today we have given the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jia, who is working in China for human rights and the environment.
But because he was in prison, he could not take over personally.
Shame on China! Tomorrow there will be a debate on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, we must not only value economic interests, but above all human rights.
We demand freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as a rapporteur for the Office for Fraud Control, one makes interesting experiences, such as the one that everyone is talking about fraud control and nobody is doing anything about it.
or the experience that the Member States with a sharp grip calculate their payments to the European Union but when they spend this money they put on their spending pants
and even cheat on it. For example by the fact that it still takes 36 months on average until irregularities are reported to the European Union.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We want an efficient fraud prevention that includes prevention.
We want the Member States to make fraud prevention a topic and that we discuss the necessities and problems for this together.
We want a greater interest of the national justice authorities in the further prosecution of OLA's prosecution results.
In crummy tours, there may no longer be legal-free spaces like before.
We need a balance between European money and national money.
We want an independent office that has the necessary resources and legal foundations to fulfil its tasks.
And we want an office that can work together with member states without noise and efficiently.
Our statement on the legal basis 1073.99 shows all these points.
We plead for this resolution to be further developed as a core of the Office for Fraud Control together with the Council.
We call on the Council to work on our position. We call on the Council to begin discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We want to solve the problems of Olaf.
I thank all the high court parties for supporting this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Presidents to take up the ball of the Parliament and to play it back.
We have also adopted solutions that the Council Working Group has developed and introduced in our proposals.
On our part, I would like to say that we are interested in a quick conclusion of this regulation and to ensure that you are prepared for constructive discussions based on our proposals.
A consolidation of all Olaf's legal foundations, as the Council has foreseen, means an additional considerable loss of time with uncertain outcome.
Olaf is soon celebrating his tenth birthday.
A consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal framework.
For this, we are too serious about the fight against fraud.
We want to realize the possible now in cooperation with the Council.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President, I would like to make a remark that my Austrian colleague Paul RÃ¼big mentioned earlier.
We are spending less than 1% of the European GDP on Europe. At the same time, we demand that more and more tasks are done by the European Union for more and more member states.
This calculation cannot be made. It is therefore really unbelievable that we have been driving a savings rate for many years. But not only in the saving

and there are many tasks that Europe could use in the field of student and student exchange.

But, and this remark has already been said many times, integration must not be too far into traditionally grown and there above all into functioning structures.
Not everything can be broken down into one piece.
Public documents and public personnal documents are in many Member States quite different.

This must not be played out without any reason, just because there are no such professional groups elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and cross-sectional opening, yes, but with a certain extent.
Thank you very much, Mrs. President. Dear colleagues, Pesticide, goods and products are essential agricultural products.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products, because it is about protecting the local culture, high-quality food and the protection of resources.

Children and politics, the interests of citizens and politicians rarely go so far apart.
In the citizens of all Europe the topic of children is at the top.
For politicians, children's interests are at stake under far-reaching laws, as we can see here again.
I don't know any country where there is a separate children's ministry. There is also no separate representative for the interests of our youngest citizens in the Commission.
In the parliament the topic of children is spread over all committees.
That is why I would like to emphasize that the Commission is currently working on children's care facilities and Barcelona goals.
Thank you. In our parliamentary work group Quality of Childhood we have found the following. Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is here, now and today, who is a child, is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb up on the social scale or fall down.
It can stay in its own cultural circle or look for a new one.
It can take a similar path of life as his parents or do exactly the opposite.
It can be someone of another or of their own gender.
All this was more than 50 years ago, when we lifted the United Europe out of the coffin, completely different.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans has become a determining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity therefore has to find its way into the pedagogy of the teacher and the educator.
This is currently being taken much too lightly.
The children's care facilities and schools in Europe are breaking down because of the challenge of integration.
In integration questions we have to press the reset button, back to the start.
Let's look at this topic once again, without prejudice, according to the motto of unity through diversity.

And beyond that, I ask all the European Parliamentarians who follow me, do not just vote for gender mainstreaming, fight for children's mainstreaming, especially now, in the time of the global financial crisis, because otherwise we would be indebted to our children. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I want to make this very short.

I would like to send out two messages at the end. First, I expressly thank the commissioner for not speaking against the concept of minimum requirements of the security network.

The problem is, we didn't do exactly that.
This conversation has never taken place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you to be open-minded and to say let's talk about a compromise
to impose the fundamentally opposition to the minimum standards on the completely irrational, competitive and environmentalist, unreasonable resistance.
I think that this is the point where we can reach a compromise, which I hope we will get in the second reading.
By the way, I do not think that we should seek a compromise in a first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.
I do not want to end this legislature as a rapporteur and leave a legislation to the next parliament, in which a law text is discussed that is not consistent, that is illogical and contradictory.
That is why I ask for your support for the compromises if we vote in one hour. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, I think the crucial question regarding all the conjucting programs that are being run all over Europe is, of course, who will get the money in the end?
the banks are still being issued more blank checks, although the rapid nationalisation would ultimately be much cheaper for the taxpayer.
and should the corporations and the high-income families be even more relieved of their burden, even though they have been mended throughout Europe by tax gifts for years?
The more money is wasted for such purposes, the more likely these programmes will fail and the more likely it will be that the European economy will sink into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, liberalization, precisely this policy has concentrated the incomes of the upper 10,000 more and more. And it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we are today.
And who believes that he can overcome this crisis by continuing this policy with minimal modifications, I think he simply did not understand anything.
The exact opposite is necessary.
Instead of buying the banks' lazy papers, tax funds should be used for the renovation of schools, hospitals and for the ecological reconstruction of the European economy.

As long as private companies receive public funds, no tax money without employment guarantees must be applied, and above all no tax money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can be involved in future payments.
The best possible conjuctural program that would exist at the moment would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from top to bottom.
The hunger wage sector in Europe must be pushed back instead of being further and further promoted.
We need higher minimum wages and better social services in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and the profitors of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have arisen and not the large majority of citizens who have never received anything from the whole financial boom.
I think that the social justice is also the only sensible thing in the current economic policy.
And it is the only way to break through the devastating crisis dynamics.

Thank you, Mrs. President, Mrs. Commissioner, dear colleagues. The report of Mr. Van Nistelrooy on the Green Book and the future form of the cohesion policy is certainly one of the most important of the regional committee of the last years.

and a sustainable development of the highlands with different characteristics and characteristics and at the same time to preserve their diversity.

of the GDP must be created so that these regions can maintain a clear status and thus have more security in their development.

Thank you very much, Mrs. President. Thank you very much, Mrs. President, Mrs. President, dear Mrs. Commissioner, dear colleagues. One thing is clear ahead of the time. The removal of food for the needy, especially in these economically difficult times, is not in my opinion in the upcoming vote on the report of our colleague Sikirski.

It seems to me that the president is a bit symptomatic for us, the EU in general, but also for the parliament in particular, that we are conducting reflexive discussions about situations in countries whose situation is not new.
Unfortunately, night events often lead to us suddenly pouring into political demands, which I find somewhat questionable.
I think that it is not well in our eyes to launch a failed plane attack alone to a general debate about Yemen.
I think we should be clear about the fact that it is well in our eyes to think of a strategy for dealing with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen needs an exact analysis, namely that it is a failed state in which a government acts that no longer has control over large parts of the country and we should analyze for ourselves what risks arise from it for Europe.
The risks seem to be that terrorists are being trained there and the risks seem to be at the coast of Yemen where piracy is obviously taking place.
That is why I think it is up to us and perhaps also to Ms. Eschten to consider what we can do about these risks
For my terms, the answer can be above all how we can strengthen the government in Yemen, regain control over the country and curb these risks.

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country must of course be conducted. I don't think that will be the goal in Yemen, but we should focus on what kind of help we can provide in the current situation to solve an acute problem. Thank you.

Political coherence in the interest of development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

For example, it makes little sense to invest funding in the development of agriculture in developing countries if we at the same time destroy the local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can also use ourselves even more for better health care if we prevent trade with generic drugs or increase drug prices by patent extension to an unbearable level.

And agro-fuels might reduce the CO2 emissions in the EU a little, but in developing countries they lead to deforestation and land use and thus to more climate change, which we just wanted to avoid. Not to mention the distribution of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity and the use of agricultural land for food.
At the moment we, that is the EU as such, are not particularly coherent.
The EU has long recognized that policy measures should not contradict each other in theory.
In the Treaty of Lisbon, political coherence is determined in the interest of development.
Article 208 states that the EU will consider the development cooperation goals in the implementation of political measures that can affect developing countries.
We must be able to meet this demand.
This year we are checking progress in achieving the Millennium Goals.
It is clear that without political coherence we will not succeed in fulfilling our promises.

We must become aware of this responsibility, like all of us who decide and implement laws. Before we decide a measure, there must be a follow-up assessment, so that we can at all recognize what negative effects the European legislation can have on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, the Commission and the Parliament that recognizes inconsistencies.
The Commission's work programme on political coherence is a good step
And now it comes down to how this plan is implemented.

Political coherence in the interest of development means that we must take more into account the interests of the people on site during the fisheries reform and not be allowed to subordinate the interests of European fisheries corporations.
It means that we have to drain out tax oases into the money flowing from developing countries.
It means that we cannot agree with ACTA if there is a suspicion that this agreement could disturb access to drugs or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the Commission has not been able to clear this suspicion.

Political coherence also means that when creating the foreign service, development policy must remain a strong, independent political field and that the competence of the development commissioner must be expanded and not restricted.
And it is also part of the process of making fair trade possible in the municipalities, as my colleague Heide RÃ¼hle suggested.
In many cases, we have to look closely at the Commission and the Council so that they can make policy coherent.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us to be coherent in the interests of development.
We need to network better between the committees and we need one or more permanent rapporteurs.
The report, which the Development Committee has received in a consistent manner, makes many good suggestions and brings us one big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the ombudsman and all the NGOs for their help and cooperation and hope that our joint report can be received by the plenum tomorrow.

And you expect that this predator-finance-market-capitalism will be caught up again and that the primate of politics will be restored.

and he pleads for stricter rules of capital, then this is an appeal to this Parliament to really constitute these rules.
It is the matter of the European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to urgently take an effective regulation. It would only be the first step towards a status quo.
Let them finally follow the full-blown promise of deeds. My faction stands for a strong European regulation.
Everything else, no regulation would be a danger to the Euro, to a common EU and democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. This is a bad timing for this speech.

But on the subject, Mr. Commissioner, yes, you are giving the right hand sign. Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, we are closing today, or tomorrow more precisely, a bill package that we have been discussing for more than two years.

But I think if we draw a conclusion to this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we are now voting on a compromise, where it is definitely worth saying yes to him, even if you do that at one or the other point with a poked fist in your pocket.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One is the environmental requirements in industrial plants.
It is about better implementing the best technology in Europe.
I think we have found an exception in the current compromise that the EU-Commission, Mr. Botocznik, and this is very clear in your address, gives the tool in hand
in the next few years to make sure that the 52,000 industrial plants in Europe use the best technology available in the world.
I heard many arguments in this debate
I want to take one example and reflect it here, because I cannot comprehend it at all.
It is often said that the use of best-available technology is too expensive and that we are threatening the competitiveness of the European industry, even more so in the crisis.
I don't like to remember my past, but I come from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also to be attributed to the fact that over decades the investment in the last years of technology has been asleep.
I believe that every industry, every industrial company is challenged to invest in the last stage of technology because otherwise it loses competitiveness and reduces the emissions of the waste.
I think we have the chance to enforce a law that will improve this situation.
The second part of the guideline, and this is a bit the fangs that I mentioned, are the major fire systems.

We are talking once again about new exceptions until the year 2020, sometimes 2023, for large-scale fire systems that do not have to meet the environmental standards, especially the air pollution limits.
I am addressing the Council here, but maybe also a little bit to all of us, that we have to think very carefully about how meaningful it actually is that we regularly

to welcome ambitious environmental goals, which are also discussed and are welcome here. But whenever it comes to implementing them, to adopting concrete legislation, a game of chess begins in Europe.
Then it becomes clear to the Member States what it costs, what bills to pay and then usually those who have gone into advance are punished.
There are a number of member states that have already fulfilled their resolutions today and are left in the rain in the end.
And I say it again here, both in industrial plants and in large-scale power plants, which are essentially coal-fired plants, we are not talking about science fiction.
We are not talking about things that are not available, but it is the last stage of technology.
best available techniques, what is available on the market under competitive and cost aspects can be built into these systems. And for this reason we conclude
I am going to present a bill today, which I believe is better than what is in force. And that is why I encourage you to agree to it.

And I also thank the colleagues who have worked with very hard bandages for the last two years for their support, for their commitment and above all that almost all important factions have signed this compromise. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Three things happened while we were debating. First, it is clear that Europe will become world champions in football.

because unfortunately our colleague Bas Aykut is already gone.

I wanted to say two aspects to the debate that I was just allowed to follow.

One has to be able to afford high-level environmental protection.
Yes, that's right.
But I think that even if you consider this sentence, it is worth it to agree on this compromise, because it will be justifiable to this different exit situation, which many member states are in.
And secondly, the argument that the use of best-priced technologies is a threat to competitiveness, especially in China. This argument is not only wrong, it is even dangerous.
We have to deal with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are definitely cheaper than in our country.
And we will only be able to compete if we use the best technology in all industrial branches.
If you don't do that, you lose competitiveness.
Nobody demands, not even this law, to shut down an industrial plant tomorrow.
Nobody demands the jump from 0 to 100 to reach a target value within a week.
We have enough transition periods. But to say that you should not do this for competitive reasons is wrong.

And I think that we have not only completed an environmental policy, but also an industrial policy transition. It would be worthwhile to work in the coming years. Thank you very much. Thank you, Mr. President.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to begin with a thank you to the colleagues of the other parties for the creation of my report on Kosovo. Also to Mrs. Eva Marr, who has done a very valuable job here in the Secretariat.

of Kosovo and of independence. And to make it clear that the common future for all states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo and all others, as a member of the European Union, is set and that the problems that still exist have to be solved along the way.

because the citizens of the country, especially the young ones, should not have the impression that they live in an isolated state. They cannot go out while everyone else in the environment will soon have this future.

Thank you very much, Mrs. President, dear High Representative, dear Commissars. Dear colleagues, the latest events in Kyrgyzstan, the violence outbreaks, the slaughter of people,
The burning of houses and the floods of thousands of refugees who left their home towns and tried to flee from violence, all of this shocked me and the suffering with the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan are also a highlight of the situation in Central Asia, which should not leave us untouched here in the European Parliament.
On the contrary, we should devote all our attention to the countries of this region.

We should not only focus our attention on the countries that are rich in land and that are of special economic interest to us in Europe, but also on all countries that are equally important in the framework of the Central Asian strategy, which was decided in 2007.
I think that's our duty.
The states of Central Asia, which not even 20 years ago freed themselves from the once Tsarist and later Soviet rule, bear a heavy legacy.

The border drawn by Stalin without consideration for the home regions of the peoples living there, are apparently making it difficult for the two countries to live together within and outside the borders.
Poverty, corruption, mistreatment of human rights and minorities, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions, for example in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, hundreds of thousands,
and force the immigration of workers and, as we now in Kyrgyzstan admit, conflict resolution with violence, let the path of these states into the future be marked with question marks.
Here we are not only allowed to watch the European Union,
If we do not want to lead the way of these states into fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to deliver people there to a dictatorial regime, it will require our full efforts.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we need the contact with these states, the active support for the democratic forces developing there.
If we give the Minister President Rosa Otunbayev a chance to bring about the reconciliation of Kyrgyzstan and to stable political relations, we will allow the debate and the voting tomorrow

and the resulting resolution, so that the people of Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian countries feel that we are not leaving them alone or delivering them to undemocratic forces on their way to the future.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high. We should not disappoint you. Thank you very much.
The report was approved for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, which we will still have to worry about.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, I am very much for green genetic engineering, but cloning is something different.
You can't compare that at all.
Cloning is animal torture. And many colleagues have already said it here,
I also mentioned it before the summer break in the discussion we had. Only a fraction of the animal clones are actually survivable.
And those who survive, many of them die very early, very miserably.
They suffer from abuse of extremities, of organs.
they have immune weaknesses, they are susceptible to diseases.
This means pain and suffering and this painful death.
How can we answer this?
We are committed to animal protection and we want to support such a technology.
No, we don't want that. And that's why we decided in July that we don't want to have clone meat and no animal products from clone animals.
And that is only consistent.

Yes, we know that the products from the cloned animals or their descendants are probably not harmful to health and I personally assume that they are actually suitable for human nutrition. But there is actually no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we let ourselves be influenced by this clone?
It is completely unnecessary to carry out this animal torture. And the population does not want it either.
The population does not want these products, we do not need them either. There is no argument for clone meat in the European Union.
And that's why we want a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and also for their offspring.
I want a ban on cloning and cloning products in the European Union. And I also believe that we can do that.
Of course, this also has to do with imports.
And I want to be sure that I don't get cloned meat because it's not marked as it happened here in
I do not think that you can pursue all the meat back.
It may be possible with beef.
But with pork, due to the mass produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether it was actually a clone in the herd.
Basically, I think, yes, it is a fundamental question, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said that we also have to deal with ethical issues and we are responsible for ethical issues.
And of course there is the issue of animal protection, but there is also another issue.

The experience shows, I am an animal producer, I studied this, the experience shows that all reproduction techniques, as soon as they really worked in animal production, were ultimately also applied to humans.
And today we have to ask ourselves, can we accept the clone technology in the near future, even among humans?
So I don't want that and I can't do that either.
And even if a replacement clone could donate a vital organ in the future, a clone of myself, then I wouldn't want that.
And I don't think that this is an exaggerated vision of horror.
I believe that this would not be possible in the future if we allowed cloning.
And that's why we urgently need a ban not only from cloning, but also from cloning animals and their offspring throughout the EU.
And I have no fear of the WTO.
We can do this.
We don't have to do everything the USA wants us to do, with all transatlantic friendship. Thank you.

and the implementation of European decisions and goals are still subject to the member states according to the principle of subsidiarity.

and in a continuation of the cohesion and regional policy beyond 2013, mountains, islands and the other areas will also find their place.

I am very happy for the transfer of technology, but our companies must also see a sense in investing in it. Therefore, the intellectual property must not be improved.

But they must be credible and they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise we will do the exact opposite of what we want, namely they will distance themselves from us.
So, to appear in Cancun is an important point.
The very big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but I think we should prepare the field in Cancun.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, there will be no harvest.
Let's concentrate on the good stuff.
Thank you, Mr. President. The President has given a pretext to the European Council this morning, which I do not want to go into myself, because I was the target of an insult.
But I want to say that there are levels on which I cannot be insulted and where I do not feel that as an insult, because to insult me you have to have a certain degree of seriousness.

I would like to thank you, dear colleagues from all parties,

Dear Commissioner, Minister, Gosses, colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, I am happy that we have now made the step that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is put under European direct supervision.
This is also a step for a strong Europe in an internal market, for strong control over a sector that contributed to the crisis.
I would like to make one more remark, dear Mr. Barnier. At the moment, the selection processes for the new authorities are ongoing and the new authorities are only as good as the staff.

I can only hope that the selection of personnel will be about expertise, independence from the financial industry that they should control, clear service to public interests and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that go beyond these important criteria.
In addition, there is still a lot to do in the area of rating agencies.

We still do not have the proper transparency of the information with which the rating agencies work. We have way too much use of regulatory ratings in the financial industry and in the regulations about the financial industry.
We have serious conflicts of interest, we clearly have a market power of three major providers and we have no hold over negligent ratings.
That's why I'm asking you, Mr. Commissioner, it's good that the consultation is now underway and we're curious about the results
and I think that the civil society should participate in this consultation. But then it has to be about making a brave proposal
I am looking forward to your suggestions
Be as brave as you are and let's make laws together next year that solve the problems that still exist in the rating market in Europe.
This is our duty as citizens.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues, which damage rating agencies can set up, the last months have shown this since the beginning of this year.
There is a urgent need for action
And that is why I welcome, or in this respect I welcome the guideline, especially that ESMA would transfer the supervision and registration of the rating agencies.
I think this is an important and good step forward.
However, numerous good and continuing proposals remained on the agenda during the negotiations on the report.
I would like to point this out.
The commission of ESMA remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database for the creation of ratings have also been dropped. Likewise, there is no evidence of the establishment of a public rating agency.
The consistent and continuous examination of ratings created by the supervisory authorities has also fallen under the table.
The Commission has also proposed a promotion of non-commissioned ratings to overcome the negligible emittance orders for the evaluation of financial market products. Nothing has remained of that.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the upcoming reports on this topic, which Jean-Paul Groset and you, Mr. Barnier, have also spoken about. Thank you.
Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I would like to thank those who worked on this report, especially Mr. Benson.
I want to point out two points of view and perhaps make them a little more thoughtful.
We agree that energy efficiency, energy saving, is the solution. The simplest and most reasonable.
The question is how do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to ask the question, what has it actually brought that we in the parliament have repeatedly approached people with new and higher percentages?
Did we really achieve more and move more?
Or why and at which points has energy, is energy, been treated more sparingly?
I learn that the industry that consumes a lot of energy, deals more sparingly with energy because it saves money and because it is cheap for it.
And I learn that people, when they know that this device consumes more energy or less energy, so when they see that and can decide for themselves a disadvantage, then they will decide for it.
And perhaps the method is not to work properly with percentages, but to use the method properly to move forward with incentives.
Second question. The commissioner has just very impressively and clearly presented how complicated the description of the term is. What is that actually?
How different is this in the member states?
The colleague just pointed out that the member states have completely different situations, economically, geographically, totally different.
Is it the right answer to work with one number, with one binding number, or do we not have to come up with more?

I think we have to take a step back from the debate of the past, which with simple numbers, with binding conditions and with such a miracle solution, thinks we can do something. Because obviously we haven't done enough.
Maybe we try to take the other way, the differentiated, the different answers, which takes up different situations and locations, but then also achieves an effect.
It depends on the effects. It does not depend on our presence.

which has clearly demanded that the European Parliament get certain rights in order to maintain its credibility within the institutions and towards citizens.

and this is especially important for services that exceed the limits. Equal treatment is required here.

It is important that the EU deals with the problems of migration and asylum.
The Commission has proposed appropriate proposals
At present, there is no precise analysis of the implementation of the existing legal regulations,
There are also hardly any mature calculations and analyses on the new proposals.
I must note that the EVP, without restriction, is entitled to asylum and to protection for those in need.
However, the view of reality also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is taken into account for completely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidized protection is not an instrument for the general immigration of the 27 member states.
We also have to make sure that the organized human traffickers do not get a chance to raise their Rai-Bach to billions over our asylum rights at the fate of human beings.
Asylum procedures must be carried out in a qualified and careful manner.
The persecuted must have the guarantee to find protection in the EU.
That is why the Commission has provided the appropriate obligations in the new drafts.
I think many of them are correct, such as interpreters, proper health care, consideration of special protective requirements.
I would also like to point out points that I find problematic.
The authorities of the member states receive far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of speeding up the procedure and the limit procedure should be restricted beyond the fee.

If a party member massively violates his or her duty of participation, there are hardly any possibilities for sanctions. Quite the opposite. If he or she appears illegally, the Member State should not be able to terminate his or her procedure. If he or she appears again, he or she should be granted an extended range of procedures.
Even if the reason is obvious, an accelerated procedure should be possible after the second order of the Parliament.
This means considerable costs increases.
The free legal advice in the form of a lawyer is currently a considerable cost increase for the states, according to the draft of the Commission.
I simply ask the Commission to consider the consequences of its proposals on the practical reality, the financial impacts and the problems for the administration of the member states.
We want a high standard, but it must also be feasible and must not put particularly burdened member states in completely impossible positions.
Mr. President, thank you very much for letting me take the opportunity to say a few words.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, the Commission is announcing a successful competition policy in this report.
It should not be forgotten, however, that an unregulated competition can also contribute to the rise in unemployment and the gap between the rich and the poor.
The unhindered competition in the European Union is still ranked ahead of the social needs of the people.
The credo for free markets cannot be overshadowed by the fact that they are not only failing again and again, but are also incapable of constantly establishing social justice.
A few procedures regarding competition disqualifications and price defaults do not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time social domestic market only works with a strong and fair regulation.
For this, more is urgently needed.
For example, it is unacceptable to always put the facilities of public presence in the private-economical competition.
The report states the comments for the future competition policy of the Commission.
much stronger consumer protection, the exception of public property from competition rules and the control of cartels. All of this is urgently needed.
In addition, a contract clause for a secure social progress, which is at least at the same level as the competition rules in Europe, would be necessary.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is a really important hour that we are first in the European Parliament today to commemorate the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti.
And let me begin with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy wrote to Robert Reinhardt in 1943 before his deportation from a German orphanage to Auschwitz.
He wrote, I found my parents again.
We are on the way to the concentration camp.
I have wrung myself so far inside that I can endure death.
I thank you once again for everything you have shown me.
Greetings to all, goodbye in the sky.
Your Robert.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return to the world like 500,000 other Roma and Sinti. And although Roma and Sinti became the first victims of mass killings together with Jews, today, 66 years later, the full truth about it has not been spoken out.
And the co-victimship of the majority society is often ignored.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust in Roma and Sinti must be perceived and recognized as a crime against humanity, so that this story does not repeat itself.
We have to fight the prejudices against these people with passion.
Racist hostilities and violence, as it happened in Hungary last year, for example, we have to provide for with civil courage.
Freedom, equality and solidarity are not a privilege for individuals, but the right of all, because human rights and civil rights are inseparable. Thank you.

and the other points in our writing, legitimize the question of a fundamental question.

Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I expressly welcome the result of the mediation process.

With the implementation of the regulation, it will now be possible to ensure that, in the area of power bus traffic, there is a high level of protection comparable to that of other traffic carriers for all passengers, including those with limited mobility.

and the consumption of people. Secondly, a high general consumer protection level is ensured. And thirdly, the special features are taken into account, that it is a traffic sector mostly characterized by small and medium-sized companies.

This is why the extreme demands, which would have made bus traffic almost completely impossible because of exaggerated demands, are the same as the demands that would have completely eliminated the majority of Member States from the application area of the regulation.
Bus services that are generally suitable for citizens must also offer disabled people and people with limited mobility a high quality.
You should have a claim for help. In the interest of social integration, this should be free.

Thank you very much, Madam Chairwoman. I would like to congratulate all of you, especially on the colleague Kanzian, for his efforts in the difficult and tedious work of a compromise in this difficult dossier.
There were successes that were already counted, but there were also disappointments, such as the area of ââreporting and other tips that were already presented.

The next necessary step is to create a coherent and efficient framework for all passenger cabins.
Just and clearly defined rights are of special importance for the EU's credibility with European citizens.
And to be credible, the coherence of the rights for the different types of transport must therefore be respected.
It is no different for the rest of the fleet passengers fundamentally other criteria apply as for example for passenger trains.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, we are in a big economic crisis, we have been talking about it for months, that's all right. But we usually talk in subtitles and then continue to decide here as if nothing had happened.
I think it's because we in parliament are not acting concretely and honestly enough. It's a kind of headline politics that's happening.
What do you really do to promote growth and stability?
Do we also contribute to the finance of a more decent and smarter way of dealing with it?
We really have a critical examination of whether we make the right spending or not every day each of us has a new idea where we can spend money.

If we don't have the strength to concentrate the financial resources on future projects, and that means disputes, discussions and decisions, then it makes no sense to talk about innovation and research, but not to make the resources available
is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to encourage economy, we have to make a policy that encourages economy and not think about how to disturb industry or economy from morning till evening.
We are making bold and continuous decisions, and are constantly demanding new decisions, which are disturbing the economy in its development.
Does anyone believe that the question of binding energy efficiency, to give just one example, contributes to the fact that the economy is being driven forward?
Do you really believe that we have managed to do business with our decisions, which we have often made in connection with energy,
or did we disturb them?
And I would like us to talk about this a little more honestly and then make a few less decisions, but maybe the decisions that really make the difference.
That is more exhausting, more tedious, will also mean conflict, but that is the meaning of democracy.
Yes, thank you. Colleagues, the demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. Globalisation opponents have been demanding such a tax for many years.
But only five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week it is on the agenda in the European Parliament together with a CO2 tax and Eurobonics and I think that's good.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments proposed by Anni Podimata in her report and I think we will also vote accordingly.
They are urgently necessary instruments
The consolidation of public households has so far focused solely on the reduction of expenses,
The shortening of public spending, however, primarily affects workers, pensioners and the poor, those who are dependent on the social state.
The public hand's side of the income has been completely ignored so far.
It is the second screw on which you can turn to consolidate public households.
Above all, however, the main causes of the public debt crisis and the withdrawal of public debt can be appropriately involved.
To consolidate public households, increasing tax revenues is simply inevitable.

In fact, the high debt of public households is above all a consequence of the statehood of private debts, namely the taking over of the debts of private banks and the financing of the following financial crisis by the public hand.
The responsibility for the debt crisis is therefore not carried out by the states alone.
It is therefore not only up to the public, but also politically, to ask the financial sector to pay the bills.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be involved as the main cause of public debt, in the withdrawal of this debt.
This is an important political signal that is derived from this report, if it is so said as it was presented.
But we also consider Eurobon for a useful and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than any sanctions or more or less well-meaning advice.

However, the complaints of some excess-countries that their interest rates are rising through Eurobonds are not acceptable. At the same time, these excess-countries also earn through their exports to the deficit countries.
This can be criticized as a transfer union.
But if you want a social Europe, if you want the EU to stick together in the future, you have to agree to a transfer union, at least in the basic principle.
Finally, I would like to say to the Commission that I hope that it will finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been requested for over a year. Thank you.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the rescue ships should protect EU member states from the inability to pay.
but they overtake the people with brutal savings programs and leave the perpetrators unscathed. In addition, the Commission is now also involved in national wage policies.

to say that wages should reflect market conditions.

Why don't you then start today?

With this, Ms. Gabriele Zimmer has the floor. I would like to ask the two representatives of the Council and the Commission why they believe that we should speak about this issue.

And then to talk about it, we hope that the LDC will become more shock resistant, I think that's already slowly becoming cynical.

Mr. Barnier, if you say you want to promote social integration in this context, then I have to ask you, I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of tariff agreements.
These are the basic rules that you, as you say, do not want to question yourself.

If one wants to protect basic rules, one must ensure that elementary social standards are protected in the future when issuing public orders, that tariff agreements are not cancelled and that wage dumping is pushed forward.

Dear Mrs. President, dear Mrs. Commissioner Kruse, the radio frequencies are a valuable and limited asset that can be managed with care, foresight and under general social aspects.
That is why the Radio Spectrum Policy Program has a very special importance.
Radio frequencies must be used efficiently under the consideration of economic, social and cultural aspects.
In order to achieve this, technical possibilities must be used in full extent in all areas of the band, in order to achieve the greatest possible efficiency.

The basis of the radio frequency policy must be the telecom package that was approved last year. Because it was also determined that the radio frequency management of the EU and its member states must equally meet cultural, social and economic interests.
This must be taken into account, especially when it comes to harmonizing frequency usage in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the Digital Dividend I has so far been implemented in the Member States at a very different speed.
Another opening of the ORF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered considering the experiences of clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions have not been solved yet.

And especially the problem of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural facilities and local localities with the technical equipment, for example in the area of radio microphones, is not yet solved satisfactorily.
When distributing the frequency bands, the different interests must be balanced responsibly.

On the one hand, the broadband network provides a basic demand for the interests of European citizens. At the same time, a development in the area of public and private radio is also important as an instrument for the consideration of information and cultural diversity.
We must correct the changes in the technical development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology and cultural diversity.

and the costs of supporting the weaker countries are increasing.

When will the Commission propose

What do you do to make it go faster?

Mr. President, dear colleagues, dear visitors, the cultural diversity of Europe is an important asset to be preserved and to be expanded in the future.
To make this possible, we must not only place ourselves in the information and knowledge society, but also in the cultural and creative sectors, in the digital age.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
In the EU, about 5 million people are engaged in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to about 2.5% of the total employment.
The cultural sector is a sector of growth that is developing faster than many other sectors of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content offered by the cultural sector in the same way as the type and quality of the content has changed and developed further through technology.
We therefore need framework conditions for the culture and creative industry in which it can develop sustainably in view of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and legal system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and creative industry is a motor for Europe.
And that is why we have to pay attention to this area in the field of school and professional education.
We have to teach young people and also in the offers of lifelong learning cultural and creative competences.
But we also have to strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of culture creators. And not only the entrepreneurial skills, but also a good media competence in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which to create culture that can ensure their livelihood.

And that is why we will have to deal with the issues of copyright, social security and the issues of intellectual property, but also the open access to information and content in order to continue developing

in the creative and cultural industries in the future in a digital environment and to be able to preserve the cultural diversity and the cultural heritage of Europe as a fundamental feature of the European Union.
Dear President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues, today we remember in particular the mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These smuggles are one of the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was not only and not least because of this and not unjustly called a century of expropriations.
And today we all bow down to the victims of these inhuman acts.
We demand a clear explanation of Soviet history and Stalinism, especially the horrors of the war.

Today's Russia should not see this as a political attack, but as a support for the elaboration of its own history, which is exactly like the history of other European countries marked by sun and shadow times.
But as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We remember the so-called exchange of population between Turkey and Greece.
The deportations in Europe reached a special point in the middle of the century by the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The exiles after the Second World War also inflicted deep wounds, as well as the exiles during the Yugoslav War.
We must not forget, however, that many colonial rulers were marked by expulsions.
We must seriously consider the different forms of displacement and the reasons for the lack of money.
And this includes the clarification of the guilt and the punishment of the guilty, as far as is possible, as is now the case of Mladic.
But the decisive answer is European unity, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries and a clear commitment to the continuation of the not yet completed European process of unity.
This historical task is what we are not only ourselves, but especially the victims of many evictions in Europe, guilty of.
Many politicians from all countries of Europe, from East and West, have worked on this.
Let us think for example of the Tancig declaration signed by the Polish President Wojniewski and the German Federal President Rauch.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be growing, also in the face of the first approaches of the traditions, such as in the case of Rome.

After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogies, it is now time for voting. The political package, the great compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future identification of food.
This regulation is intended to provide consumers with more and better information about food so that they can make a decision about buying it.
But that's not all. The European food industry should also benefit.
Right-safety, demilitarization and better legalization are the goals.
This is especially important for small and medium-sized companies. And one must know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80% of SMEs.
At the same time, this label must be suitable for every food and for every non-alcoholic beverage. From basic food to high-processed ready-to-eat dishes.
That is why a compulsory label in light-colored colors is not possible, because this label does not fit on basic food.
Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in the parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise achieved can be seen.
Allergies will be recognizable at first sight.
The plant origin of plant oils is specified.
There is a trademark for pork, for chicken, sheep and goat meat.

For other products, a follow-up assessment will show whether and how the origin can be specified, for example for milk and dairy products, single ingredients, i.e. products that consist of a main ingredient, meat in processed
and other products. Imitations on the front have to be clearly marked and the same applies to the meat and fish, put together and glued together in small pieces.
A packaging must not also evoke the impression that something is inside that is not inside.
If a picture of fruits is on a yogurt, fruits must also be in it and not just color and aroma substances.
In addition, there is the obligatory use of the most important nutrients, always per 100 grams or 100 milliliters, for reasons of comparability.
Water added to meat must be marked. The date of the first deep freezing of meat and fish and many other details.
The most important thing is that all information must be readable.
We defined legibility. We determined a minimum font size and commissioned the Commission to determine binding rules for other factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we protect the craftsmanship from too high costs and bureaucracy.
Fresh products that are not pre-packaged must deliver the allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information that can be determined by expensive analyses.
The Commission wanted this to happen, but that would have destroyed our national and regional specialties and specialties. It would have led to the European unity pie and that is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the serious consumer protectionists are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

Ms President, Mr Commissioner, dear colleagues, in view of the currently extraordinary situation due to the financial, economic and household crisis, decisions should be made on an European level on urgent and essential issues.
This is the only way to restore our citizens' trust in the seriousness of our actions.
In my report, it is about the strategy to avoid infinite human suffering resulting from about 35,000 deaths annually and
4.5 million often severe injuries due to road accidents, as well as the prevention of a public-economical damage of 130 billion euros per year.
The number of deaths alone is the equivalent of the number of medium-sized transport aircraft that would be complained about if the crash of 250 fully-powered vehicles.
What would we not do to prevent that?
The accident cost exceeds the annual total budget of the European Union.
That is why I am sure that we are well prepared to continue our activities in this area.
Thanks to the constructive work of all the shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, we have succeeded in creating a consistent approach to improving road traffic safety.
It takes into account the contents of the UN Charter for Road Safety 2010-2020 as well as the contents and goals of the traffic safety work of EU Member States and broad circles of civil society.
It contains ambitious but realistic goals for the time to come and with the vision of the time beyond.
So, by 2020, the number of deaths from the accident will be reduced by 50%, the number of children killed by the accident by 60% and the number of seriously injured by the accident by 40%.
This is in the very own interest of every single one of our people, but also of our economy.
We recommend that Member States break down their goals and methods onto their territory and expect from them their own traffic safety action programs.
It contains, secondly, who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is not only the case for the European Union.

In the sense of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that the Member States, regional or municipal responsible companies, and even every single traffic participant, have the responsibility to take responsibility in the sense of their duty to contribute.
And it contains, thirdly, how, i.e. with which instruments, activities and measures the goals should be achieved.
Legislative proposals on a European level are only one strategy.
We cannot and will not give up on guidelines, recommendations and orders.
The subsidiarity was particularly taken care of. This means that responsibilities and responsibilities were clearly mentioned, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the diverse activities of the Commission.

But since they come from the most diverse general directions such as traffic, economy, consumer protection, the environment, communication, research and development, the domestic market and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes they contradict each other.
That is why we are proposing the implementation of a coordinator for road safety within the European Commission.
This avoids sustainable development of a road traffic safety agency, but increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
The choice of measures and their evaluation both require a scientifically-founded approach based on comparable, qualitatively high-quality data definitions and statistics.

We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of the causes of injury and accidents, as well as the EU-wide exchange of data under the supervision of a high personal data protection level.
Six main fields of action were identified.
They concern people as traffic participants, road traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking and the special consideration of the weaker traffic participants.
I ask for your consent tomorrow.
