But as I said in this report, I hope that the expectations of the Parliament here do not remain a frowned list of wishes, but that a goal will be achieved by 2020 and our proposals become reality. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, it is just 20 years ago that the Central Asian states achieved their national independence as a result of the fall of the Soviet Union.
Coming from a dictatorship, the construction of democratic and right-wing structures in these states remains a constant challenge.
These countries are equally important trading partners of the EU and their member states due to their abundance of soil and raw materials.
It is therefore only correct to regulate the EU's relationship to these countries within the framework of partnerships and cooperation agreements.
Partnerships and cooperation agreements should serve cooperation and lead to partnership action, but not to one-sided stigmatization.
Child labour and especially forced labour of children is unfortunately a disease that is still widespread in many countries of this world and needs to be fought.

However, I would like to remind you that it was common in many agricultural-oriented European regions to extend the school holidays of children during harvest time and to give the children from farm families the opportunity to help in the harvest, which today no one would call forced labor.
If there are signs of forced labor in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other states where there is still child labour, also for those states where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude than in India or China.
We should not measure with two measures.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, dear colleagues, I can only join the rows that congratulated the Presidency.
In difficult times, you were not only an honest broker, but also a European broker.

I think it was very pleasant to feel in these difficult times, where we have political currents in a large number of member states, which suggest to people that one could achieve more alone than together.
and you have put the common good in the center
It was also very refreshing to see that you found consent in Poland in the internal political debate with this clear European agenda.
It wasn't easy in this context.
and also the highest respect for what you have done.
In this half year, we were able to bring some things into the way, especially in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may only take up one topic that I was allowed to discuss myself, namely the issue of regulation of uncoversed loans and uncoversed credit loss insurance for state loans, where the Commission did not dare to propose a strict regulation, where we were told by all

When the Member States were told that they would not be able to get through and that thanks to the Polish Presidency it was possible to sanction a highly speculative instrument and, where necessary, to ban it, so that we can contribute to more stability in the financial markets,
I would like to express my gratitude to your Minister of Finance and the Secretary of State, who have brought this into the way in a tedious discussion process between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of how we can do something together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Thank you for that.
Since yesterday, colleagues, the new surveillance mechanism for economic inequalities has been in force.
In the meantime, the specific regulations are also in progress.
What kind of development does the Commission see as dangerous? What economic problems does it want to know corrected?
The Commission sees a growth in the wage cut costs in euro countries of more than 3% per year as a problem.
A limit for decreasing wages is not provided.
Cheap, dear Commission, does not mean good.
It is not enough to force the Member States to reach prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health and energy efficiency, we can exploit our employees to the bone. But we will not write economic success stories like this.
Another example is the SCORWAT. The loss of export market shares is to be checked and sanctioned.
That is nonsense.
With increasing global trade, Europe's shares are statistically forced to decline.
The indicator punishes the countries that are already in the global trade.
That is why we think that the Commission should withdraw this scoreboard and sign a general meeting. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to thank our rapporteur and everyone who worked on the report, because it is not routine, even if you have dealt with competition policy on the basis of a report by the Commission for the 40th time.
I would like to thank the commissioner, because the year 2010 was the year when you were fully responsible for the competition policy for the very comprehensive presentation.
I would like to ask you to explain that we are currently working on a certain process in the banking sector,
because now, due to the new stress test of the European Banking Authority, a new capitalization in the banking sector is being urged.
and I don't think that all of this contributes to the stability of the banking system. On the one hand, we have a multitude of irresponsible or not-conclusive old-timers.
and in fact new cases are already arising due to the pressure being built up to increase the capital quotas, especially in the private sector.

So here is my urgent request, Mr. Commissioner, to come up with a quick solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector in such a way that it can also face the challenges in the international environment.
The second major topic, diffusion control, will also move us in the coming years.
I can only ask for the clear and transparent way to continue, which has been introduced by the Commission as part of the fusion control.

I believe that it is in the interest of all participants, especially of consumers, that we ensure in the area of fusion control that competition, even in larger or other structures, I do not want to evaluate that, is possible in the region.
In this sense, I would like to thank everyone who has worked here. I hope, Mr. Commissioner, that we will soon find a solution in the banking sector. Thank you.

Mr. Commissioner, I think you just hit the nail on the head by saying that we are all together able to start a third industrial revolution in Europe, if we understand that we perceive sustainability as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also talked about resources and there you bring me to a thought that I totally forgot today.
I forgot the human resources in my office.
And Ms. Philipp, please allow me, you have been a great success. You were a very leading person in this matter.
And I would like to thank you for that.
Thank you, Mr. President. For freedom of speech in the parliament, you also need a microphone system that works.
The button to turn on the microphone broke.
I would ask that a technician restores the freedom of speech. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mrs. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I am amazed that we have to remember again and again what is actually understood under structure and cohesion policy.

Coercion and structural policy is one of the central areas of policy in the European Union and it is to serve as a definition of the establishment of economic and social cohesion in the community and to promote growth and employment in the underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy has proven itself in the years of the crisis.
In many regions, it seems much more difficult. As far as economic development is concerned, these funds would not be available.
The implementation of the structure of funding is based on operational programs. The funding strategy of the respective regions is described in the program.
The European Union, Member States and regions work together in partnership to create a real European added value.
The success of the cohesion and structural policy is also based on reliability of the programmes and the available and available means.

That is why I am very surprised when, again and again, from member states, but also from the Commission side, as we can see now, the structure fund funds are being tried to take up as a scapegoat for all possible current political approaches.

This is not justified by the purpose and the purpose of the coercion policy and it also uncertainizes the actors in the regions who are already working on the basic long-term strategies and contracts for achieving their goals.
Certainly, the fight against youth unemployment and the use of economic growth are important goals
But this will only be achieved if the partnership between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and the actors in the regions are included and remain.
because only they have the knowledge of what is necessary to do in their regions.
Coercion and structural politics are the unifying, partnership and solidarity band of action between the individual political levels in the European Union
In it, the solidary Europe is visible in the regions and it should not be given up easily due to political quicksand.

Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner. I support the compromise found in the trial, which is to strengthen the negotiating power of the dairy farmers against the processing industry, although I know that it does not solve all problems in some member states with which the dairy farmers are currently confronted.
50 years ago, Commissioner Manzhold had proposed a priority measure for the creation of producers and communities in the Rheinland.
In my country, Luxembourg, the dairy industry is the main source of our agriculture due to the high proportion of green land.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join forces in a partnership that takes care of the milk production itself.
Five Member States have voted in the Council for exactly this reason against the compromise, which is not justified by its provision as a soft landing instrument.

The European Commission has the initiative right to make legislative proposals, and therefore I would like to challenge it to make a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament in 2012 to correct this obvious and costly mistake in the system.

A linear reduction of the super-discount for every kilo of milk supplied until 2015 or the abolishment of the fat correction could at least weaken the negative effects of the current regulation without damaging the non-involved member states.
The previous milk package is also understood as the conclusion of the high-level group, which is supposed to bring the milk quota to a gentle landing.
It is astonishing that there is no mention of milk quotas in this report.
Young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and in four other Member States are trying to expand their production on the liberalisation of the milk market.
to keep up with the global market after 2015, can only do this by buying more quotas even now, shortly before the end of the milk quota system.
This is an enormous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure, which you have been compromising against your colleagues in 22 Member States. Thank you very much.
So please, the blue card. Question. Is it known to you that we have community loans for a long time?
and that the resolution does not speak in a simple way of Eurobonds, but of very different options,
And is it known to you that not all these options require a change in the contract?
I find it questionable that you have again denounced generalities about Eurobonds.
We should not give up on the differentiatedness that we have achieved with the good proposal of Mrs. Goulart.
I would like to hear a little more differentiation in your statements and I am curious what you think about it.
I'll just say briefly, dear colleague Guldaar, this is not a review I have made here.
I just want to point out that the last Italian state loan before Italy went into the Euro, was 10% interest.
and there was no cry out in Italy and nobody said that other countries should take over
It was natural that one paid high interest rates.

and now suddenly, because you had low interest rates for ten years and you owe yourself to all means, because money has become cheap for investments as well as for public hands, then you want to prolong this over Euro bonds
This is a trap we can't get out of and I stand by that.
Thank you very much. Mr. Commissioner, your answer really disappointed me to some extent.

They obviously want to stick to the old system, that one has to conduct complicated negotiations per country and that, again, no further access to literature is provided, that no more possibilities for blind and visually impaired people arise.
This is even more sad for me, because the EU is now blocking a step forward in the WIPO, while all other or many other contract partners are ready to move forward.
Here a huge opportunity is missed.

They are not fighting for rights for more owners, but they are fighting against people who are guaranteed the same access to cultural assets as the Convention on the Rights of Abandoned People and that they can also participate in these cultural assets in a comprehensive way.
I appeal to you, please build barriers and vote for a binding treaty.

Dear colleagues, the discussion here in this house shows that we represent the entire range. On the one hand, those who do not wish any restrictions, on the other hand, who associate any form of immigration with the danger of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I think one has to consider the family relationship with a great sense and also with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in Member States in which too restrictive measures are taken.
Because family reunification cannot be done with so many obstacles that no one can be brought together anymore.

On the other hand, it is completely justified that member states, for example, require language skills, that they require integration, that they also require the willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, the Member States have the right, and we should not put these problems aside, to formulate the problems that arise in the family cooperation.

If countries like Greece or Malta or even Romania or Italy are no longer allowed to formulate the problems they have in this context, then I don't know if we are democratic anymore if we simply ignore problems.
I don't think we need a new guideline.
I think we should discuss the problems carefully and then think about how we can eliminate problems
The constant re-production of guidelines does not lead to the improvement of the guidelines and their implementation.
We have some implementation problems

And I have full understanding that we have to deal with it first, that we don't make a new guideline again and put something on it before we have discussed the old guideline in any way in its problematic.
I am for the fact that you listen to the member states and that you at the same time respect the fundamental right to family cohesion
and if we do this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will come to a good way.
Mr President, PomyÅl zanim pomyÅlisz. Think before you think, says the Polish aphorist StanisÅaw Jelcz. This recommendation has been good for us in this Parliament so far.
A few weeks after the resolution to Central Asia strategy, which was cancelled in this House, in which the Central Asian countries were censored, now strikes in Janna-o-Zen
in Kazakhstan without the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being conducted under international supervision.
As much as the dead can be accused, the injured and the imprisoned, as a result of these events, have the right to process the events, the backgrounds remain unsuspected.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the opposition party ALGA, said, quote, that was a group of other people. The unrest is not in the interests of the protesters, because that only provides the reason to act violently against them.
Central Asian expert Arkady Dubnov said, quote, that it is not excluded that parts of the Kazakh opposition, who live abroad, also mix with it.
On the other hand, it could be a good idea to keep the tensions in the Kazakh capital Astana in order.
After all, the power elites of Kazakhstan are already fighting for the successor of President Nosulta Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in the parliament.

UN Special Officer Miroslav JenÄa has announced today that he is impressed by the attention of the events of Janos Osen by the Kazakh government, that it is necessary to uncover the true background of the UNRWA.
We should take the Kasar authorities at their word, measure their actions, but not come to reflexive prejudices.
If I understood you correctly, the statement you gave today is that yes, the Commission is fighting for the continuation of the food programme for the most needy people in the European Union.
It will do everything it can to present concrete ideas in the foreseeable future. A. Where the programme will be located. B. How it will be financed.
I think this is urgently necessary and I think that we are responsible for ensuring that this food program becomes a reality.
not because I think it is the ultimate ratio, but because in my view it is a signal to show people that we still have a basic feeling for the necessary solidarity with the

and the life situations of people in the European Union who unfortunately could not participate in a development and who became the first victims and the greatest victims of the way of combating the crisis by the European Union.
I am thinking of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where exactly what we as the European Union are doing is mainly at the expense of the poorest of the poor.
We put a sign, but unfortunately it is not more.
I think it is urgently necessary that we not only depend on the 18 million people in the European Union, who are dependent on food for now,
but that it has to be about the fight against poverty, or at least to put it on the top agenda, on the top spot of our own agenda.
We have not yet conveyed this signal.
But in my view, this is the crucial point when we want to move forward and when we want to gain trust among citizens of our European Union, that we really form a social and solidary union.
In this sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, have also been called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have blocked so far must give up this attitude.
I think that's a bit of self-imposed duty for us.
Dear colleague Dohl, I listened to you carefully.
What you suggest, in parallel with the subsidiarity test, is to present a growth test for all expenses. This means narrowing the goals to growth.
I would like to know from you how you can bring this together with the claim of a Christian Democratic Party, which probably still knows goals beyond growth.
It should be known in general that the economy does not bring children into the world, does not attract them and does not enable them to live in a natural environment.
This means that the priorities are being changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they are being considered.
As a party, we will check very carefully whether what you have proposed today is in fact a priority change.
Until now, the motto was that only the economy needs functioning financial markets.
And that's what it was all about at first, to restore public finances, to pay off the debts and to keep the markets quiet.
And Mr. Dohl, who is unfortunately not present now, I actually just wanted to tell him that I would like to keep it exactly the same as Georges Marchais.
I didn't understand his answer, but I would object to it.
I think the measures that have been introduced were wrong.
They were not right. It was not right to rely solely on the renovation of the economy and to completely ignore what happened to the people.
It was not right to put the stability of the euro above everything else and to say that what will become of the people is completely irrelevant to us.
It has to be the other way around. First it's about the people, then we can continue talking about the euro-stabilisation.

The speculative attacks on Spain brought the interest rates for Spanish state loans to more than 6% and thus close to the interest rate levels of other countries such as Greece, Portugal or Ireland, which have taken up the support of the rescue fund.
and the saving policy imposed by the EU, the ECB and the IMF on the member states with the drastic reduction of public spending of all kinds
the reduction of wages and pensions, the increase of the VAT and much more, has burdened the citizens and not prevented the recent spiral.
Rigorous shorting of state expenses, intensified decline, drives up the debt rate of states. This must be our common understanding.
When Mr Draghi said recently that the European social model is at its end, I am happy, Mr Barroso, when you say, no, we in the Commission do not think so.
But then I expect from you that you go to Greece, that you send your people to Greece, Portugal, Ireland and that you register exactly what is happening there.
What happens to the people who have to fight for survival?
What are we doing together to stop this spiral of suicide, which has been used in the most affected countries of debt?
It can't be that we watch here without doing anything.
And we don't need social-political programs that will be used at some point when other measures have taken place.
We have to act now. Where did your goals from the 2020 strategy for fighting poverty remain?
What has become of the European platform for poverty?
It has been put aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the midst of a crisis, people need help, they need support and they need the European Union to act.
You don't need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas of what should be done now.
If you do this, my party will get the support
Support all those who, even within the Commission, have recognized the signs of the times and want to change things.
But please don't just go on like this and say,
There will be nothing left if it goes on like this. I am asking you to present a concrete project, a concrete programme, which will now be able to help people in the affected countries actively.
Do something about it!
We will have to do it in our countries so that the money for ESF 2013, 2014 and 2020 is not blocked, or that it is cut for the other programs.
that the Member States will follow their responsibilities. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, the current situation of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a tax policy fairy tale.
The situation in the council is simply that there is little progress in tax policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are against further tax cooperation
They benefit from aggressive tax planning. They are themselves tax oases.
And in the contracts it is clearly stated that there is a unanimous vote on the tax issues.
That is why the EU Commission has suffered shipwrecks with its proposals several times in the past
They are being diluted, they are not advancing as in the interest rate guideline and in the new proposals, in the pre-emptive obedience, nothing demanding was proposed.

I am asking you, Mr. Schimeter, I know your job is not easy in this regard, change the strategy, introduce strict measures and then set up the increased cooperation to end the blockade position in the Council.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, with the proposed proposal, no state bankruptcy will certainly be prevented for the risk assessment instruments where it should occur.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing.
Extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The debt crisis in some countries led to an extraordinary situation in which important projects and measures cannot be carried out in the context of cohesion and structural policy because the banking sector as a financier is falling out and private investors are no longer available.
An extraordinary measure, I see in the proposed proposal to create risk-division instruments for further financing of projects in structural politics.
By means of cohesion and structural policy, the countries that want to use these sharing instruments can be used for financial security of already ongoing projects.
I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Danuta HÃ¼bner, for her very precise contribution to the Commission's proposal and for clarifying when and how these instruments should be used.
But I also believe that these risk-division instruments are only to blame for the current situation and cannot be a prejudice for the future funding period.
After three years of testing and four studies, the change in the Biometric Pest Regulation was demanded in 2009. Our party supported this change.
And that's also because it has always been causing great concerns for data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the benefit of biometric data in travel passes.
The belief in the perfect identification, the overestimation of this means and, what results from it, the underestimation of other elements of the security chain are really problematic.
The handling of biometric data still contains this big mistake, namely the assumption that they are unchangeable and most trustworthy.
And that's not the case.
These data are also changeable in the course of life.
Children look different than at a young age.
And that is why reliable and serious studies and conclusions are necessary.
Still, they are falsely accused.
I have now been able to determine
as is the case in the UK and other countries, the chips are not safe against abuse at all.
They are cracked happily and can cause permanent damage to those affected.
The EU standards are also very different.
The error rate is very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
And again and again the question has to be asked what biometric data will benefit us if documents are falsified and are in circulation.
If one of the components in the chain is faulty, the starting documents are incorrect, biometric data should not help us.
One last thing. The Chaos Computer Club in Germany only needed a few minutes to demonstrate a fraud.

The Chaos Computer Club friends needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a super glue, a digital camera and a little wood glue. In a few minutes they had cracked the chip. So much for the supposed security.
We expect from the Commission the outline of the studies and of course the results and the consequences that arise from it. Thank you.
Dear Council, unfortunately the Commission is not represented enough today as I would have liked it to be in respect for the Parliament.

As a member of parliament from a region that is massively affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, I am interested in the question whether the only attempt, which is not suitable for the parliament,
of the criteria for disadvantaged areas really meets the needs of these regions. Especially since the necessary information is not available for a meaningful and responsible decision.
Above all, I wonder if an adequate impact assessment was carried out.
We need to be fair to the farmers not only biophysical criteria but also socio-economic criteria

Therefore, I urge the Commission to review the criteria in this important aspect with the necessary time, free of the total package of the GAP reform and above all according to the template of the necessary documents and careful analysis of the effects.
I believe that we have to work with the asylum support office and the Greek authorities to identify which people who have come to Greece could be

and also to other European Union countries, because they can't return to their home country and also because they can bring potential and qualifications that can be meaningful and objective for everyone.
But in essence it is also about helping the Greeks to register and identify themselves faster, to allow faster help processes to proceed.
to bring back those who have neither qualifications nor the right to stay in Greece or the European Union, because they actually have a chance to stay in their own home countries.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Ms. Commissioner. Thank you very much also to the rapporteur for her always very engaged and exemplary work.
I can share a lot of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has expressed, I support this or have partly supported this.
But there is always the point when you have to take responsibility.
For the EVP and for myself, I take it into account that we must deal with the realities now and cannot withdraw from ideological or theoretical points of view.
The fact is that the USA has been collecting this PNR data for 10 years and there was not a single complaint.
The fact is that we all don't want the data traffic, even with a declining attitude, to be able to stop the data traffic at all.
You just did that.
Fact is also that we do not want the air traffic between Europe and the USA to stop.
And the fact is that the USA have a right to know who comes to their country.
And in my opinion, the fact is that the legal services have all told us that this agreement is better than the other agreements, than the alternatives.
That is why we have to take responsibility here.
And we were elected for this.
Responsibility for the citizens who would otherwise be left alone and with less protection and rights.
responsibility for the airlines, which otherwise, and the commissioner had also done, would be left in absolute legal uncertainty,
but also responsibility for the EU as a partner in the field of data protection and security, and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, we are in the sum, also under the consideration that this agreement is not perfect, but in the consequences, to agree to this agreement

And if you want to protect the citizens better and if you want to let the citizens access better data protection, you also take on this responsibility and agree to this agreement. Thank you very much.
Yes, thank you very much, Mr. President, thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner. These were comprehensive presentations you gave us.
Thank you very much for that.

The numbers sometimes say more than big words and until today, the European Parliament, you have also mentioned it, has issued almost 2000 patents on plants and almost 1200 patents on animals, which were created with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I can mention two outstanding examples. The approval of patents on genetically modified and by breeding modified seed. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Therefore, our farmers are affected as well as our brewers, producers, as well as we consumers.
and this example shows, in my opinion, a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example, the so-called long-life tomato. Not to be confused with your long-life oil that you have in your diesel engines.
With this trick of the US-contractor Arcadia, this patent was passed to the valid EU rules.
It was not patented the tomato, but its genetic material, namely selected enzymes.

This shows what tricks are being used here. And this, although, as you said, Commissioner, in the Biopatent Directive of 1998 in Article 4 CLIP and CLAR it says, plant species and animal races are not patentable. A and B, essentially biological procedures for the breeding of plants or animals.
We believe that this definition must be more precise, it must be explained more precisely
Technical procedures that are used to support conventional breeding are not allowed to be patented in general.
We say, concretely, no patent on life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with exhaustion, again against patentability in life throughout Europe.
Therefore, Mr. Commissioner, we demand the clear statement of the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and remain banned in Europe
Second, we demand a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive, no patent on life
Third, we demand a clear determination of the privileges of farmers and farmers throughout the legislation in the name of many farmers and many farmers in Europe. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Madam Chairwoman. I take the position to dismiss Europol and Eurojust.
To Europol. There is little to do here, actually nothing to do.
The year-end results in all essential aspects of the financial situation in 2010 and all transactions are in principle and therefore also legal.
The only noticeable thing is the high transfers in relation to the overall low costs.
Europol is now moving back to a new central station. This is understandable.
But Europol says yes to further measures to be taken in the future to avoid such high transfers.
Furthermore, Europol wants to control the implementation of the household plan monthly from 2012 onwards.
I recommend that we keep this in mind, whether this really happens.
In this context, I recommend the release of Europol.
The financial situation in 2010 also reflects the end of the year in all essential aspects.
All transactions are legal and prescribed here.
but here too, high operating expenses were transferred into 2011.
According to Eurojust, this was mainly due to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure and costs in connection with data processing.
It is announced that all this will be improved in the future, also to better meet the requirements for the expiry.
I recommend that we also check this in the future and above all to check whether all open positions will be occupied in the future.
This has been improved.
But if these stations are not occupied soon, then we had to think about painting the streets, and that would be negative for Aureus.
I recommend relief. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear Commissar, ladies and gentlemen, what must frighten us and put us into panic is not the sheer number of young unemployed people in Europe alone, but the development.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of young unemployed people increased by 26.5%. This is what the International Labour Organization has determined.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only coupling a whole generation from the labour market, we are coupling a whole generation from a viable future.

If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we don't need to be surprised that young people turn away from this EU because they don't have a reasonable working and living perspective.

Commissioner, I am asking you urgently to ensure that decisive countermeasures are introduced. I can already see a lot, but please ensure that the long-term mental windfall does not turn into operational hectic.

If I read that the Commission is starting a program, after young people, when they apply abroad, are now also financially supported, then we will organize a hiking circus, which will not solve the problem.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive. Then technicians, doctors, engineers and care personnel are rejected by the countries that are richer, that are not in this crisis.
In this crisis, the cause for this development is needed. Offensive measures, namely the destruction of this savings, which affects the economy in Europe,
We need a targeted growth policy, we need an increase in the purchasing power, public investments in education, research, alternative energies.
That would be the way.
Combined with European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that would give young people a life perspective.
Last remark. With this unemployment, there is no doubt that the age of pensioners for people over 70 is not an accident.
We need a different policy that will give young people access to the labour market.
That is why I urgently ask for it. Thank you.
Ms. Kollegin, you just said that everything that would speak for the FGC would be speculation and then came up with very speculative examples.
I would like to know from you what you think about the studies of the Commission, which clearly states that so far the real economy has been far too little involved in its dependence on

that 95% of the companies are not dependent on it at all when it comes to money-saving. And that you can turn a negative growth effect, which we have talked about before, into a positive one, by spending appropriate growth-supporting public investments.
Is this just speculation for you or would you say that such a well-founded, widely-established study of the Commission already has its justification and represents a strong argument?

Yes, thank you. Yes, colleagues, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been in discussion for many years. But I think it takes on essential elements of the Tobin tax.
At least it takes on the idea of involving the financial markets in the taxation and above all to involve them in the costs of the crisis.
I think this is a very important signal to the financial markets
but it is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There were a number of member states, a number of actions, petitions, written submissions to politicians to finally introduce a financial transaction tax on a European level.
I think the parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that has signed up for this report, for this tax.
Certainly, this is not sufficient to stabilize and limit the financial markets as it might be necessary, but I think it is a really important step that has been taken here.
I expressly appeal to the Council to take the voices of citizens and voters seriously and to take action
that there will be a real introduction, that the introduction of this tax will not be blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax and I think it is a great responsibility

It is now in the hands of the Council to become active here and I would like to use my time to appeal to the Council to do everything to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.

Dear colleagues, I think that we should talk about one thing in the future, when it comes to all the problems of detail that we can talk about and that are still to be discussed in the further legislative process.
be clear. Financial markets cannot function according to the model that if everything goes well, the banks will cut the profits and if something goes wrong, the taxpayers will keep their heads down.
And that's why it makes sense to take financial transactions of a tax.
And it makes sense to cross the line.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we will not have bribes, but we will be able to provide a permanent contribution to getting a stable financial position, which generates what financial positions are actually intended for, namely that the companies

that the savers have the opportunity to save something or to put the old-age care on the side and that the financial markets can fulfill the task they were given this time, namely to provide an added value for the real economy.
All that drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create value for the real economy
That is why it makes sense to make a contribution to this through a tax, that this is punished, sanctioned and controlled in the sense that capital fulfills its task again.
That is why I am advertising this proposal today with a large majority.
Thank you very much. The reform of the general preference system was absolutely necessary.
It is good that there are longer running times and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too inaccurate, as the development committee has already said.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to World Bank-leveling.
The Parliament has repeatedly and critically discussed the GDP as the only criterion.
The definition of countries with a raised middle income can be applied to countries with a GDP of 4,000 or up to 12,000 dollars gross domestic product.
This is a huge and far too large range of events. And it is not going to be fair to the realities of the region.
that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait will find out, we certainly do not find it questionable.
The reform was good in that respect.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China, on the other hand, are countries with a high middle income. We certainly don't have to worry about their loss of the APS.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Until now, the Commission has at least brought the criteria for vulnerability with it. So countries that export little or only export very little goods.
This avoids the fact that countries that are dependent on export less products and are so vulnerable have been classified too high.
Why did the Commission then draw up these criteria?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji Islands, Gabun and Botswana will therefore fall out, although their economy falls under the criteria of invulnerability.
Why didn't the Commission continue the old criteria, which were already insufficient anyway?
There is a suspicion that the Commission wants to force poorer countries into more unfavorable free trade agreements.

However, the preference system is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by purely commercial instruments, in which the development path of a country or a region does not play any role at all.
Fortunately, it will still give the colleagues in the plenum the opportunity to agree to our amendment, which takes up the vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also means that trade regions will be torn apart.
Neighbour countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
And the Commission should consider developing regions instead of individual countries.
Here too, we have submitted a change request to the Green Party, which will hopefully find a lot of approval.
And it is also problematic when countries that benefited from the APS yesterday are to fall out of the program from today to tomorrow.
There must be transition times and that not only a few months are enough for economic development, we see in our own countries.
Finally, we have to consider whether we want to only focus on speed in all legislative projects and then work with wind-sharp compromises, or whether we would prefer to integrate the entire plenum.

I think that for legislation the whole parliament is important, for democracy as well. And not the time and not the speed is important, but it takes time to implement democracy and to properly approve laws. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Speaker. I was also a member of the European Parliament's election monitoring committee in the Democratic Republic of Congo and I was able to determine how much hope and expectation people had for a better future at the polling stations and waited to vote.
We know today that these expectations did not come true.
Although the Congo is called democratic, these elections were not fair and not democratic either.
We have to address this offensively, as the colleague Nedeljewa also did in her report.
The former president, Joseph Kabila, has named himself the winner of the election. The opposition is suppressed.
In the east of the country, the violent conflict between government troops and so-called rebels has rekindled and whether third countries like Rwanda will join in is unclear.
The civil population is definitely suffering, which has not been able to live in peace and quiet for decades.
The wealth of the country is being wasted in a swamp of corruption. The Congo remains in all the international ratings on one of the last places.

The international states, communities and especially the European Union with their possibilities, must increase the pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow real democracy in his country. At the next regional elections he has the opportunity
and that the Congolese army not only drangles the civilian population, but also finally arrests and courts internationally sought criminals like Bosco and Ganga.
Internationally, all countries should finally commit themselves to no longer delivering weapons to the Congo
Without pressure from the outside, human suffering and poverty will not end in this country.
Colleagues, with the 2-Pack further rights of access to crisis countries in the Eurozone are to be created.
The European semester, which was created as a framework for a necessary and better coordination of finance and economic policy, should get its teeth.
After the Commission's decision, member countries should be forced to accept financial aid.
With the six-pack, far-reaching sanctions have already been created that can be used against Euro-states with financial problems.
The European semester is already being perceived by the citizens as a democratic development, as a useful economic policy instrument.
At the same time, the German government openly threatens the Greek citizens with a throw-out from the Eurozone, if they decide wrongly during the election on Sunday.
Why don't we stop with these humiliating and undemocratic threats?

In a situation where the Euro crisis has again dramatically spiked, I think of Spain, of Cyprus, it does not continue to bring us member countries into the crisis, which are in crisis, to the pranger.
We should finally develop solutions. The report editors of the TUPEX have developed quite sensible approaches to this.
From Elisa Ferreira, the reference to the pension fund would be a worthwhile and useful measure to fight off the debts.
But the proposal of John Paul Gauzet of a government-run state-insolvency is also wrong.
But it is central that Europe makes a joint and solidary effort to bring the Eurozone back on the growth course.
The strong countries in Europe must stop showing their partner countries with their fingers,
You have to start doing your homework and invest in growth and take on your responsibilities.
The one-sided saving policy of Merkel simply failed as a solution to the crisis.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman, dear Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. In June 2010, the EU government heads finally recognized that the European Community needs a better coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, you invented the European semester, so to speak.
It is absolutely right that the members of an economic and monetary union are not allowed to pay attention to how their policies affect companies, employees and consumers in their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
A domestic market without coordination in economic, wage and social policy is tempting the member states to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbours.
Such inequalities can bring the Union of Welfare economically but also politically to a brink.
And the EU is currently facing exactly such a situation.
The German economy has been digging up water for years. No impulses through investments and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has driven the Eurozone into ruins with a decade of aggressive export policy.
That is why it is very pleasing that the Commission is now slowly making recommendations in its country-specific recommendations on this core problem of the Euro crisis.

The Federal Republic is rightly demanded to invest more in education, research and childcare and the Commission is rightly demanded to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to adapt the wage growth to productivity growth.
This is a later but important realization
And I hope, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rehn, that you vehemently support these demands of the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for excess countries.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, First of all I would like to thank the Commission, especially Commissioner Barnier, for the simple reason that the experience from the last legislative period, the one before 2009,

was that, with the exception of a very short moment of awakening when the proposal of the European private society came, the predecessor of Commissioner Barnier, Commissioner McCreevy, the right to social rights actually let a deep sleeper sleep. And we in these five years of this important question, which is also of importance for the domestic market,
before they arrived.
This has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there are a lot of consultation documents of the European Commission, an expert group that has developed with the question of the further development of the social law. We have now a consultation with which we as a Parliament of course also deal.
The Court of Justice has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report requires additional time and is of course a little more detailed.

We have chosen the means of the oral inquiry to the Commission to discuss this topic with the Commission and with Commissioner Barnier and at the same time to make clear our position as Parliament regarding what is to happen now.
I think it is necessary, similar to what we had 10 years ago, to develop a new action plan for European social rights. For many reasons.
There are gaps within European social law. Real gaps that lead to the fact that the internal market is not made.
I want to give an example. The lack of the 14th line for the seat placement. Most doctors think it is a typical example of such a gap.
The Parliament has demanded twice in legislative and initiative reports that concrete proposals of the European Commission be put on the table.
There is also the expert committee, which the European Commission itself has called upon, which also has the same opinion on this.
It simply belongs to the basic freedoms in the internal market that a company in the internal market can also move in terms of its registered seat.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

In the background, however, I must also criticise the fact that the previous opinion of the European Commission on the 14th Directive actually clearly lags behind the expectations of the Parliament and, in our opinion, does not meet the standard of a qualified answer to a legislative initiative.
but we are confident that this proposal will be found in the action plan in the course of further work.
Another important point in the social law is the question of the further development of the social law with the aim of removing burdens for companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the topic
But I think there is still more to do and other aspects that will be clarified in the framework of the consultation.
and we are also expecting further suggestions from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the topic of European private society, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If individual member states, I can say this from my own opinion, if there are individual member states in the EU, which are not able to eliminate the deadlock due to lack of their own power of decision,

to advance in Europe, then one must think about this as with other projects, such as the patent or the family law, to use the instrument of enhanced cooperation, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to enjoy this opportunity
and I would ask the Commission to think about this issue in more detail.
Another open problem is the question of applicable law, a kind of Rome-regulation for border-crossing problems in social law.
I also think that this question needs further investigation and clarification and would ask the Commission to do this.
And with that, in a close connection,
the right to pay for the insurance, but it is already announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You see, there is a lot to do in social law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken over the initiative again and it is recognizable that we will get significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period that will then be able to show progress in the design of the domestic market.
The Parliament supports this in the basic and in the approach.
We will certainly discuss the details.
But that's why I want to thank the Commission
And of course we would be happy if the Commission would actually take action on our initiatives and change the concrete proposal. Thank you.
Mr. Speaker, Mr. Commissioner, I appreciate your suggestion regarding the productivity-oriented wage policy.
But in terms of minimum wage, you have been snitching on Mrs Merkel. And the question of the development of employment in the health care system, I do not believe you.
How should new work be done if the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How should employment in the health sector be created if the Commission needs some Member States in the new, country-specific recommendations for the European semester to further reduce the expenses for health?
I suspect that this point in the plan is purely announcement policy, not a real initiative for new work.
On the contrary, even today, there is a lack of health and medicine savings, not only in Greece.
I think that if you constantly set up new rescue shields for banks, I must now use a rescue shield for people, especially for the protection of medical care in the countries in crisis. Thank you.
Yes, thank you. The atmosphere among countless pro-Europeans like me is one of a frightened horror over what is currently happening in Europe.
It is still pleasing that now much clearer is being said what we are dealing with and that the eyes are not closed in front of Italy.
You know that there are a number of cases, not only in the case of debt and growth, but also in the case of trust and power, which are appreciated by the Commission and also addressed to the Council.
Unfortunately, you have missed the opportunity to address the central question of the removal of the financial economy from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here is, according to experts, always balanced as if the shadow bank entity has not yet set a serious limit.
We still have to deal with systemic risks. Furthermore, the question of too big to fail is not addressed properly and rating agencies hardly need to lose a word.
I can only advise you to work towards the council summit, to make it a reality in Europe that you seriously question the power between the real world and the financial economy
that they finally work faithfully in front of the Europeans that the banks will be put into the boxes and not always the citizens to bear the burden.

Mr. Ferrum, you come from a country that has rejected the euro, although with the central reason that one wants to obtain the flexibility of the devaluation, especially for social and political reasons.

In light of the experiences you have made in Sweden, would you recommend to the Greeks to leave the Eurozone as well, in order to be able to actively use this social-political instrument of devaluation?
Yes, thank you very much, Mr. President. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur.
We have adopted this report in the environmental committee with a full majority of 62 votes, with zero opposition and no abstentions.
This shows that we are actually very close to each other, also when it comes to compromises.

And the highest priority, of course, must be to have a high level of protection in these legislative procedures, a high consumer protection, especially for the little ones in our society, for children in need of protection.
And as far as the gluten intolerance is concerned, this is a problem. And especially in kindergartens.
If you look around, I have two children at this age, what allergies and insufficiency there are, I think we have been there right.
and we should discuss this in the second reading with each other, with the Council, with the Commission.
and I think we will get a good result.
A report about a traffic accident on the weekend with a truck driver who fell asleep in exhaustion and was driven into a ditch has confirmed how necessary
a clear and consistent regulation of the steering and calm times and their control through a digital signpost for us, for traffic safety, but also for the affected ones.
The digital tachograph means a certain innovation. It has new problems, but also old problems.
The new problems arise in new manipulations, which we also have to get technically in control.
The old problems are those that we can observe in different Member States, when there is a lack of control.
What we are now re-regulating, in my view, has to be taken into account. First, that not every time, when no ride is recorded, a rest time automatically occurs.
because many drivers have to charge and unload and that is of course also to be evaluated as working hours.
The second problem is that the records of speed from the dossier were erased.
I think that's wrong, because there are also great dangers of accidents here.
We also want to have weight sensors and we also want to have a hotline so that you can report fraud that is anonymous and can be prosecuted.
What I will also include is a proposal that the animal transport control is included in this regulation.
I consider this important because it is also a very central element of our legislation.

Mrs. President, many thousands of people could still live today or would not have any remaining disabilities if only they were quick enough after their accident. That means that within the first so-called golden hour professional medical assistance has been provided.
We are a whole bit closer to Vision Zero.
The eCall system we are talking about today can avoid accidents. It does not deviate from the first aid obligation.
It is only useful in the event of a serious accident to automatically inform an emergency call center.
This must also be used to avoid abuse and overload by bagatelle accidents, to create verbal contact with the accident vehicle.
Only when the emergency call is confirmed or no one answers, emergency doctors are sent to the accident site with little but vital information.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system is asleep. It does not send any signals or data and is not available to locate.
This is therefore also far above the data protection of a mobile phone.
Only by activating the automatic, controlled by sensors, or the conscious manual, the system becomes active.
It then sends a set of minimal data sets of information to a rescue control station
European standards and specifications will ensure that this data is recognized as an emergency call when it is received, evaluated and treated.
That is why the Member States must also equip and expand their rescue service chains accordingly.

We want this e-call emergency call system to be based on the EU-unified emergency call number 112, to be free for the user, to work everywhere in the EU and to be compatible with emergency call systems from neighboring third countries.
It is to be based on an interoperable technology, neutral, open system architecture.
Other intelligent public transport services such as traffic information in real time or availability of parking spaces can also be offered through these.
In recognition of the great achievements of the automotive industry in providing private emergency calls, these should maintain their existence parallel to the public 112 e-call.
On the basis of detailed information, the users can also decide for such a system.
This may also have to do with the possibility of
the use of data for workshops, insurances, tow trucks or other service providers.
A small village in the Franconian countryside is known for its good beer. This rhyme shows a small problem that we have created today.

Because if this brewery or the beverage dealer is 107 km from my home, I have no chance that he will continue to offer me his goods in the future without him having to buy a new tachograph, without there being a new bureaucracy.

And that's why, dear colleagues, I voted against this decision today. Because I believe that we should not burden our small and medium-sized enterprises too much. There were many points that we got in, that were positive, thank God.
It was planned to take 50 km in the circle of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd by the EU-Commission.
100 km is still doable.
But what if it goes beyond that?
So, I think it's exaggerated.
And one last aspect, as a representative of a worker organization in the CSU, I say too, we create with this regulation a complete control of workers.
Why?
Because for example the person who offers his goods for the construction or for the drinks, for the breweries, is completely controlled by GPS the whole working day.
So I consider for data protection reasons what we have decided today to be highly questionable and I emphasize again why I voted against it.
Yes, thank you very much for this question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision
I have been waiting in the Court for the European Parliament to agree when we were still asking the necessary questions about the security of the law in relation to ACTA during the trial.
And there was silence in the forest and denial
They didn't want that. Now it's obvious that the EGH should be used as a delay. That's clear.
Why I said that with the wide interpretation space?
Because you... Because you... You asked two questions, I have to answer both of them. Unfortunately.
because you can read and interpret everything from these broad forms, the surveillance of the Internet, the helpers of ISPs,
And that means a lack of security on the right. And that also does not help our economy, dear colleagues.
Mr. Leichtfried, I would like to ask you, are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright on a European level?
or are you completely against the rejection of any spiritual property?
And how do you imagine that the e-commerce guidelines will be adapted to the modern circumstances in the future?
From your point of view I assume that you reject a debate about these things at all and do not stand for spiritual property.
Is that true or what do you think?
Yes, thank you very much. It is not about individual facts that we have to discuss, but about the basic question of how we view it with respect to democracy and freedom of rights.
And if we look at the Acta, we will find out that it is somewhat symbolic of intransparency, of a lack of democracy, of the violation of basic rights, because it was secretly rummaged out
and undemocratic, because the free use of the internet simply could not be possible anymore and also not the freedom of use of generics to the extent as it is now.
These are the reasons why millions of people have gone out on the streets and have already taken the vote on ACTA.
Yes, there was voting over ACTA, on the streets, on the internet, in reference to the petition committee, in many countries, not only within the EU,
and also outside the EU. And I believe we must not ignore this vote. This is a vote of the direct democracy of many citizens who voted for us.
I can only tell you to put down your files. That would be decent.

Mrs. President, as the rapporteur of the House and the House Control Committee I have concluded two proceedings under your presidency. The House Order, with which there is a rule set for the coming MFF period and the Olaf Procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation was in the waiting queue in the Council and you, based on the results of the Polish presidency, have brought this procedure to a conclusion.
I would like to thank you for two very, very committed financial officers who have worked on these files and who have also come to the message.
We will miss him. His efficiency as a negotiator will be missing.
You really made yourself worthy for the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here as a representative of my party and would like to support the proposal of Mr. Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This ensures that we are careful about the topic of the spiritual rights of protection.
The European Commission has presented this proposal to the European Court with the request for a decision on the clarification of open questions.
I think that it is the attention of the highest court of the European Union that we are waiting for this decision.
There is no reason to make this decision today.
Nobody is prevented from voting against it if the court has made its decision and its decision.
But the decision that is then made takes place in a different consciousness and in a different understanding than today.
I don't mean that the ghost drivers on the internet should decide our politics. And that's why I ask you to support this application. Thank you.
Thank you. As always when colleague Turmes speaks, it is very clever and one would wish that what he says would have much more influence on European politics.
I wanted to make a point of it.
Of course these project loans are something smart, but only if they are sustainable oriented and if political foundations are created for this.
We are in danger of securing risks through guarantees that we politically do not have under control.

Concretely, the energy transition in Germany, 8300, 3800 km of network would be necessary. Only 100 km of these corresponding remote networks are built, because it fails at the resistance of the citizens. Incidentally, very ecologically oriented citizens.
We have to come up with something from politics.
An idea would be to create ten corridors together, so not only combine the high-speed lines at the railways and broadband networks, but also build the line networks next to the motorway.
This requires a much more comprehensive planning than has been done so far, but I would like to encourage this at least at this point.

Dear colleagues, I think Schengen is one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. But I also know that the borders of a country are always a very sensitive topic for our member states and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems that exist between the member states in relation to Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And there are different problems.
and by ignoring you don't make the problems better and you don't solve them better either.
I live on the border to Czechia and nobody would come up with the idea to close the border just because we have problems.
But I also ask the Commission in this area for support and not for restriction and justification.
The smuggling was anchored because we want to guarantee safety while at the same time free of travel.
And if we successfully conduct the smuggling of drugs, especially at the borders of the Czech Republic, where some drug dealers, not only in a few cases, but in many cases,
try to get a transition, then I think it's good if the German Prime Minister and the Czech Prime Minister get together to solve the problems that exist at the border together.
And the Commission should not act in a regulated manner, but in a positive and supportive manner.

We want to put the populists in the box, but solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to look for a solution together with the Parliament, so that we can successfully approve the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of travel and at the same time ensure the safety of citizens.
Thank you. The cases of unrelatable border controls, which the Parliament lists in its question, also show why the Council actually wants to leave the Parliament outside of Schengen.
The council wants to continue to undermine freedom of travel without the parliament being involved in it or without any form of parliamentary control, without any form of public opinion.
No wonder you'd rather pat your shoulders in the back rooms, apart from uncomfortable questions.
No wonder that the German government, without evaluation, wants to exclude an evaluation of the internal borders completely and therefore does not want to see how much travel freedom is restricted.
Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people in Europe and thus also belongs to the European Parliament. Thank you.

Dear Mr. President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christofias, Today, for me and for my party, it is a special moment to welcome you here in your office as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also happy that for the first time in the history of the European Union a person is at the top of the EU, whom we count as our political family.
You are taking over the presidency at a time when the European Union is facing huge challenges. And now the question is whether the European Union
whether the Union will have a future or whether it will, and that would be a historical defeat from my point of view, prove itself to be a footnote in history.
I know from the conversations we had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the heads of the parties and factions in your country, that you have
that you have prepared your presidency excellently and that you are aware of the scope of your task.
But, and you have made it clear here today, you want to consciously direct the attention of the ruling class towards the life situation of the people.
And I can tell you here, after all I've heard in the last few years, it's the first time that a president of the European Union does exactly that and announces and says, this tone

I have long missed in official speeches, that it is said that it is about the people here, it is about those who are not responsible for the fact that we are in this crisis, but who have to bear the most burdens.
It will be difficult to implement exactly this approach.
I think they would have won a lot, and they will do so, I am sure, if they encourage people with their presidency and the way they are doing it.
that they are committed to their rights and that they contribute to the fact that the Council, that the European institutions are aware of this very task.
We are always talking about the euro and its stability, about the necessity, which I also see, that it is important for the functioning of the European Union and for the Eurozone.
But that is your instrument.
There were political conditions for this, they were defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union to take the functioning euro, that people in the European Union have to starve, that health systems collapse, that municipal authorities have to stop their work.
Something has twisted here.
It is not what we can call the goal of the European Union.
I support you very much in your demand that there should be solidarity between the individual member states and between the various population groups.
The European Union must not be used as an instrument or speaker for a small group of people or to present itself in this way.

And one last point I would like to address, to underline that all the things you have mentioned in your priorities are important to us and that we will support the points that go in this direction, as I have defined them.
Please do something that will make people not be afraid anymore.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
And I think that some decisions in the last weeks and months, especially during the elections in Greece, during the referendum in Ireland, were also shaped by fear.
And if the European Union's government contributes to the fear of people making their own decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Good luck in your work!
Dear colleagues, I think we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-reporting staff together,
The colleague will be very, very important in the next weeks and months to work quickly and reliably on this dossier.
The eyes are currently looking at us and the Council to take this step to overcome the crisis of the banks in Europe through another step of Europeanisation, namely through a European Banking Union.
The Parliament demanded this two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogies.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as it would have been necessary.
further billions of euros were generated
It is good that the Council has now drawn the consequences and wants to continue this step for the Eurozone.
and it is commendable that the Commission has worked out the proposals so quickly.
However, the establishment of the Council, which is supposed to become the EZB, the place of the Eurozone observer, is connected to some difficulties.
The Council is in agreement and this means that the Parliament is not in favor of the decision.
According to the experience of the inspection package, this is not acceptable

Therefore it is important that we work here in a hurry, but also that we negotiate this proposal on the changes in the ECB with the necessary changes in the existing supervisory regime as a package and thus actually create the principle of democratic co-operation of the Parliament.
In addition to this, there are further challenges in terms of democracy.
The EZB is independent in its monetary policy, but not in its fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities so far.

If you are responsible for the banking supervision, the Parliament needs full budget rights, full control rights, question rights, recognition rights and I am sure that the Parliament will also dispute these in a broad majority.

The complicated questions about the domestic market, consumer protection and the balance between European power and financial responsibility will be discussed thoroughly in the coming weeks. Thank you very much.
Thank you. With the proposal to exclude developing countries from the preferred market access, the Commission is trying to push these countries into free trade agreements.
These free-trade-dwellings, as the term suggests, are only about the interests of the EU and not the interests of the partner countries.
This is the goal of the EU, to reduce poverty and to completely oppose all external political instruments.
Countries like Cameroon, the Elvenbeinkust and Namibia would be massively affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects such as in South-East Africa would be broken if Kenya would agree to such an agreement.
The South-South cooperation would be over.
We cannot advertise free trade in the world and only think that other countries should buy our goods.
If the Commission really thinks that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The House Development Committee has recommended that the Commission's proposal be rejected.

Thank you very much, Mrs. President. The new directive will create a basis for the use of books, newspapers, works of art, films, music pieces, TV productions, which are protected by copyright, but which the right holder cannot identify or can be found.
Therefore, books, films, photos or other spiritual creations for which no right holder is available, should be made available to the public.
And so a cultural treasure is being raised.
For us in the European Council of Culture it was very important to highlight the special importance of the diversity of the cultural heritage of the European Union.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers and radio stations there are countless unused works and only because their rightful owner is not known, they should not be made available to the public.
This changes with the guideline
It will enable the use of this cultural property in the future, if it is ensured that the publication is carefully searched for.
This is a very important point, so that it is not said lightly that we do not find the rightful owners.
Because a balance had to be found with the real rights of the creators of works and the need of the public to be able to use such works, where the legal situation is not clear.
A special focus for us is that we had to ensure that both the known and the unknown rights holders are protected in full extent.
And where the rights of the owners are not found, the use of the digitization of the imported works is made possible with the design.
Projects such as Europeana and other major European digitalisation projects, but also our museums, archives and educational institutions, as well as public radio, will be started.
In the future, however, it will also be about opening the works that have been submitted to the archives of private publishers to the public.
This guideline and the compromise that has been found is in my eyes a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
And I believe that the cultural treasure that is to be found has enormous potential
And we should continue to work on this in the revision of the guideline in two years. Thank you very much.
