Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I think that today's debate on Mifid will be a key area of financial market regulation
that have been imposed in this legislative period, it is about regulating the financial markets and not just looking at individual products as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few keywords.
Last year we didn't do our work together very easily.

We have held a hearing in the committee, we have conducted a survey of stakeholders, of interested groups and based on that, we have developed a result with various processes, work documents and the like, that we present to the referendum today and tomorrow.
I want to take a few points out of this.
Topic number one, market structure.

On the one hand, we have to note that in recent years, the financial markets have done a lot. It is our interest as a Parliament that every trade of financial documents that takes place within the MIFID rules of play takes place. That is why we have been able to create a new category under many conditions.

where only non-equities are to be traded, where self-trade is to be prohibited and where, in relation to execution and transaction and interaction of the customers, a corresponding execution can take place according to their own standards.
I think that we can make an important contribution to this, that the whole area of OTC papers, which are traded within the Mifid world, is traded.
Another big topic, which was not considered in the last Mifid, is the so-called algorithmic trade or high-frequency trade.
We also wanted to make clear rules that this area, which can be very dangerous and can be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regimes with minimum holding periods,

with trade interruption possibilities, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the possibility of observing the audit structure of algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price size and through corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of the goods and appointments markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here when it comes to limiting the speculative share of real market dates so that we do not contribute to false regulations that people in the third and fourth world cannot buy food anymore.
We therefore have chosen a two-way approach with the aim of mitigating speculation but not harming the real economy.
With position limits, with strict upper limits for the number of contracts or positions we want to achieve this.
But we also want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product with a so-called position check system, that they do not suddenly also enter this market in a speculative manner.
Another topic that concerns us is the area of investment protection.
I would like to point out that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
It is about identifying the needs of certain customer groups,
Not every small saver must have access to all highly complex papers.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product tests, telephone registration, appropriate consultations, disclosure obligations, but, and I would like to point this out briefly, in the area of provisions, to make subsidies.
According to their structures, member states should have the possibility to make appropriate adjustments
I think we are on the right track.
After my time is up, I want to thank everyone who has worked here.
I think it's a shame that for such a difficult dossier you only get four minutes of speaking time.
I would like to thank all the colleagues who have contributed to the Commission's very constructive role in the last weeks and months.

And I hope that we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council tomorrow with a strong vote from the plenum and to be able to conclude this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you very much.

Ms. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, what has been waiting for a long time is finally coming to an end, I can only say that.
The report on the type approval of vehicles in the L-class has in the end become a good report.
The work took longer than we all thought and especially than we hoped. And there were many more setbacks than we would have liked.
But at this point I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr. van de Kamp for the cooperative and good cooperation.
Together we have achieved a lot in the negotiations with the Member States.
As the rapporteur of my party, I recommend that you agree to this report. Likewise, it could have been much better.
And with better, my dear colleagues, I mean safer.
For us social democrats and social democrats, safety of vehicles and therefore safety of drivers in the foreground was the most important thing. Especially safety of scooter and motorbike drivers.
The number of motorcyclists who have been missing has remained constant for years.
The number of accidents in Europe is generally decreasing, but not in the case of motorcycle accidents.
The reduction of the number of killed motorbikes and scooter drivers is indeed a matter of my heart.
Less deaths on European roads. That was and is my goal.
Every dead person is one too many.
This topic must be worked on intensively in a regulation that is so advantageous for the domestic market.
I am still convinced that this can happen with effective technologies of anti-blocking systems, i.e. ABS.
And I am equally convinced about cost-effectiveness.
It is not true that ABS is too expensive.
We have achieved, however, that from 2016 all new and from 2017 all existing motorcycle types from 125 cubic meters of lift space on the part of the manufacturer must be equipped with ABS.
The manufacturers of motor scooters can choose between ABS or the combined braking systems.
At this point, unfortunately, we must confess that we have not achieved any improvement in the Commission's proposal.
I would have wished for much more here. But the Commission and Member States have proved themselves, to put it carefully, to be very difficult.
Nevertheless, we have reached the point where the Commission presented a report in 2019.
The report must be powered by traffic accident data from the Member States and should investigate the mandatory installation of ABS in the engine rollers.
He is sent to the Parliament and Council.
On the basis of this report, the Commission is then supposed to consider making the installation of ABS mandatory in rollers.
You see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will try to close the binding gap in legislation from 2019 onwards.
I am sure that the collected data will be given to me.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for the drivers of two-wheelers in Europe and that the accident numbers will decrease in the future. Thank you very much.
